Situation1: They join in when the family talks about possible weekend plans.
Situation2: Two travelers with several suitcases ask for help loading and plan to split the fare
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, half-listening as my stepbrother rattled off ideas for our weekend together—hiking, a movie, maybe even a barbecue. My stepmom’s eyes flicked to me, her smile expectant. I knew they wanted me to join in, to be part of the family, to show I cared. I nodded along, but my phone buzzed in my pocket. A new ride request. Two travelers, lots of luggage, and a note: “Can you help us load? We’ll split the fare.” I glanced at the clock. If I left now, I’d make good money, and I prided myself on being reliable, professional—the kind of driver people recommended. But if I got up, I’d disappoint my family, again. My stepbrother’s voice grew louder, waiting for my input. My phone buzzed again, more insistent. I felt the pressure mounting, torn between being the dependable sibling they wanted and the professional driver I needed to be. My heart thudded as I stared at the screen, caught between two worlds, unsure which one I’d let down.
